be agitated or disturbed; causative: vathayati, causes to be disturbed or agitated, disturbs, agitates
determined, resolved, ppp of vi-ava-√so (vyavasyati) class 4
standing here and there, arranged, arrayed; ppp of vi-ava-√sthā, class 1
tiger; at the end of a compound, = "best of"
taken apart, wide open; ppp of vi-ā-√dā (vyādadāti)
killed, destroyed, 'caused to fall away,' past passive participle of causative of  वि -आ -√पद् (व्यापद्यते) vi -ā -√pad (vyāpadyate) a class 4 verb
literally 'causes to perish,' kills, destroys; causative of vi-ā-√pad, 'fall apart, disintegrate, perish'
busied with or engaged with, + locative; ppp of vi-ā-√pṛ (vyāpṛnoti)
gone away, vanished; ppp of vi-apa-√i
shame; in G22 it refers to Rāma's ansiety regarding what people might say about his taking back a wife who had lived in another man's house
a piece; a half (of an eggshell)
Śakuntalā, a foremother of the kurus whose story is in the Mahābhārata
Śakra, a name of Indra meaning "powerful one"
"day of Saturn" - a day of the week
an oath; with √kṛ: swear an oath
Śabarī, a female ascetic who aids Rāma
layed down, having layed down [meaning a person lying down; anyone please let me know if I'm using the wrong English 'lay']; gerund of √śī (śete)
having or possessing a body, embodied; as a masculine noun, the soul
a hare; śaśaka is a diminutive of the same but without much difference in meaning
moon; or as an adjective: having a hare as its mark
the moon having, having a hare on its face (G glossary); or as an adjective, possessing a hare (M)
weapon, cutting implement, a knife or sword
the young (of a bird or animal)
rule (Goldmans), teach, instruct, direct, govern (Maurer), also class 1 P
scholarly text, manual of instruction, book, or treatise of any kind, literally "an instrument of teaching;" science, art
head (see declensions for s stems - nom/acc = śiraḥ)
recline, lie, lie down, sleep; 3rd plural is śerate; in athematic middle tense, 3rd plural does not have a nasal, so ate, not ante. aorist: aśayiṣṭa; present middle participle:  śayānaḥ
having cool rays (referring to the moon)
"day of Venus" - a day of the week
good, beautiful, pleasant, agreeable; as neuter noun: good fortune
be dry; causative: śoṣayati, causes to be dry
empty, void, deserted; destitute of (+ instrumental or as a second element in a compound)
lance, spear (G); a stake, pike, spear (M)
possessing a trident; epithet of Śiva
a young woman (who has not had children)
the month roughly equivalent to July-August
light, lustre, splendor; beauty; prosperity, good fortune; personified as the name of the goddess of beauty and welfare, also called Lakṣmī
hear, gerund: śrutvā (note: in Chapter 26, M lists it as √śṛ but I believe this is a typo) aorist: aśrauṣīt
praiseworthy; "(going) to be praised;" gerundive of √ślāgh (ślāghate)
a period of six months, half a year
with, having (used only as a prior member of a compound)
friend, companion, comrade, feminine with long ī
"together with movable and immovable things," entire; all animal and plant life
being or existing; present participle of √as, be; as a noun (neuter) that which is or exists, the existent
a living creature, living being, being
sit (G); sink, sink down; give way, weaken, falter (M)
like, of like appearance, similar to (+ instrumental), fit, suitable
good, noble; or m. noun, a good or noble person
a hall for public assembly; an assembly or meeting
even, level, same, equal, like; indifferent
fulfilled; literally "gone completely beyond"; ppp of sam-ati-√kram (samatikrāmati)
state or condition of being equal or indifferent
all around, on all sides, everywhere
accompanied by, endowed with, possessed of; past passive participle of sam-anu-√i (samanveti) go along or after, acccompany
time, period of time (Goldmans); Maurer has: a coming together, then an agreement, arrangement, stipulation, condition
delivered, entrusted, given; past passive participle of samarpayati, which is the causative of sam-√ṛ (samṛcchati)
convene, come together (listed as samave in G glossary)
arrayed, in full array; ppp of sam-ava-√sthā, callas 1
having come together, assembled; ppp sam-ā-√gam, glass 1
come together, meet, join with (not positive about that sandhi in the 3rd p singular)
come together; having assembled; (G); having come together, gathered (M);  ppp of sam-ā-√gam (samāgacchati)
(higher) concentration; fixing of the mind on; deep concentration
get, reach, find, attain, attain or reach completely
honored; ppp of the causative of saṃ-√bhū
reach; In G22, they list as 10P, not sure if they're trying to indicate causative?
vicinity; nearness, presence; locative samīpe + genitive = near
being or situated in the vicinity, nearby
raised up, high; ppp of sam-ud-√śri (samud + śrayati - I'm not sure about the sandhi, if any) class 1 P
arisen (G); gone forth, arisen (M); ppp of sam-ud-√pad (samutpadyate?)
a lifting or raising up, effort, exertion, enterprise
go up to, approach; step up to; begin; perfect (P): samupacakrāma; perfect middle (Ā): samupacakrame
approached, come to; befallen; ppp of sam-upa-√sthā (samupatiṣṭhati)
joined or provided with (+instrumental), accompanied by; past passive participle of sam-upa-√i (eti), class 3
delivers, entrusts; causative: samarpayati; ppp: samarpita
accomplished, succeeded, fulfilled; much, abundant; ppp of sam-√ṛdh (samṛdhnoti)
come together, joined with; ppp of sam-ā-√i
battle (G); conflict, battle; field of battle (M)
having gathered together; gerund of saṃ-√grh (saṃgṛhṇāti)
a heap, accumulation (Maurer says to pronounce as if written sañcaya)
Saṃjaya, name of the bard of the blind king Dhṛtaraṣṭṛa, the narrator of the Bhagavad Gītā
be satisfied, be pleased; ppp: saṃtuṣta
pleased, happy, content, happy; past passive participle of sam-√tuṣ (samtuṣyati) be satisfied or pleased
see, regard (G) M: used only in the passive, hence: be seen, appear
"endowed with," used at end of compound
Sampāti, a vulture, brother of Jaṭāyus
full, full of (+ instrumental), filled, fulfilled, completed, quite full; M says: strictly ppp of √pṝ (piparti) class 3, meaning fill
flow together; be heaped together; causative: saṃplāvayati, causes to flow or be heaped together, submerges, inundates; periphrastic perfect of causative: saṃplāvayāmāsa
become, arise; literally "be together," then "take form"
agree, approve, highly honor, literally "think together", "being of the same opinion"
of the same opinion, agreed, approved, highly honored; ppp of saṃ-√man
perplexed, bewildered; ppp of sam-√muh (saṃmuhyati) class 4
hold together, hold in check, restrain; gerund:  samyamya
possessing control or restraint, controlled, restrained
joined, united; joined with; often used at the end of an instrumental tatpuruṣa compound giving the sense of "provided with, possessed of"; past passive participle of  saṃ-√yuj
agitated, disturbed; ppp of saṃ-√vij (saṃvijate) class 6
surrounded (chapter has saṃvrtta, glossary saṃvrta) (G); having become (M); ppp of sam-√vṛt
having wound around, having caused to wind itself about; gerund of causative of sam-√viṣṭ (saṃveṣṭate)
an impression (as of a design applied to an unbaked clay pot or of an impression made on the mind in the past, especially in a prior rebirth)
become, arise; literally "be together," then "take form"
withhold, withdraw, bring or draw together
Sarayū, the river beside the city of Ayodhyā
a stream, a river; saritaṃ patiḥ - ocean
all, each, every [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
always, all the time [formed from sarva, all, and the adverbial suffix -dā which denotes time, when
makor or creator of the whole world
politely (note chapter vocab left off virama, glossary in back has it)

bear, endure, tolerate, withstand; be kindly towards; have patience with (+ genitive);  future: sahiṣyate; infinitive: sahitum; in Ch 30 M lists this as parasmaipada but that may be a typo; in the back as ātmanepada, in G as ātmanepada.
with (used after instrumental to mark accompaniment)
straightaway, immediately, suddenly, at once (Maurer explains this comes from the instrumental of sahas, force, violence, hence it literally means "with force or violence.")
along with (G), united with or accompanied by + instrumental (M)
ocean, sea; plural: the sons of King Sagara (M23)
plural: the Sādhyas, a group of celestial beings
plural: the Siddhas, perfected ones, a group of demigods
endowed with supernatural or magical powers; ppp of √sidh (sidhyati) class 4, be accomplished or realized
having one's goal or end achieved, whose goal has been achieved
Sītā, a mythical river, possibly named after the goddess
pleasantly, in comfort (from the instrumental of sukha)
Sugrīva, a monkey king, ally of Rāma
Sucakṣus, a mythical river, name means "fair eyed"
son; comes from ppp of √sū, produce, bear, generate - the ppp literally meaning "generated, born"
very hot (from tapta, the ppp of √tap, burn); very severe (said of austerities)
daughter, feminine version of the ppp of √sū, see suta
very terrible (G); very hard, very severe (M)
Sudarśana, a king of Pāṭaliputra; also used as one of Śiva's names, and a common man's name, meaning handsome (M13) in M19: name of Viṣṇu's discus
very difficult to abandon or risk
Suparṇa, overlord of the birds, also known as Garuḍa, son of Kaśyapa and Vinatā, also known as Vainateya, son of Vinatā; his sister was Sumati, a wife of King Sagara
well disposed, very favorably disposed; su = very + ppp of pra-√sad (prasīdati) be favorable, be kindly disposed
very pleased, well disposed; su = very + ppp of √prī (prīyate), be pleased, be favorably inclined to
Sumati, wife of Sagara, daughter of Ariśṭanemi and sister of Suparṇa; name means "she who has good intelligence, wise" and she had 60,000 sons
Sumitrā - mother of Kakṣmaṇa and Śatrughna
spirituous liquor; Surā, name of a goddess, also called Varuṇāṇī
asleep, sleeping;  past passive participle of √svap (svapiti) sleep
having a good vow or good vows; strict in observing vows, very religious
a name for Karṇa meaning "the charioteer's son"
release, let go, create (M 30, 32); aorist: asrākṣit
the moon (M): G glossary just says "soma"
"day of the moon" a day of the week
Saumanasa, the guardian elephant of the western quarter
Saumitri, son of Sumitrā and Lakṣmaṇa
gentle, pleasant, mild, agreeable; as a vocative, "my friend!," "my good man!"
"day of Mercury" a day of the week
standing (at the end of a compound only) (G); M calls this a "verbal" of √sthā meaning situated, being
to stand, be situated, stay, remain, be; usually attenuated to 'be;' causative: sthāpayati, causes to stand, stops, bring to rest
having caused to stand (gerund of the causitive of √sthā (tiṣṭhati), stand

standing (G); literally having stood, standing (as opposed to going or moving), firm, settled, constant, invariable; also: stand but with a very attenuated meaning, not "having stood," but simply "being" (M) ppp of √sthā
standing; permanent condition; staying or remaining in a condition, continued existence (of the universe until its absorption), a condition or state
love - use locative for object of love
having been made clear, explained; past passive participle of spaṣṭī-kṛ (spaśṭīkaroti), class 8
used postposed to form a simple past tense
make one's own, take, receive, accept
to remember; ppp: smṛta, gerund: smṛtvā/smṛtya; infinitive: smṛtum
one's own; commonly used as a prior member of a karmadhāraya compound, such as svaputra, his son
sleep; M12 also class 2 (svapiti); gerund: suptvā
oneself, by one's self, to one's self; used reflexively and applicable to all persons, i.e., himself, herself, yourself, etc.
self-existent; also an epithet of Brahman as the ultimate principle
literally 'self choice,' the name of a ceremony at which a princess chooses a husband, or has one chosen by contest
small, little; as a neuter noun, a small amount, a little
welfare, blessing; can be used as: Hail! May all be well with you!
indeed, to be sure; often a verse-filler and meaningless, especially at the end of a verse
slay, kill, strike, strike down, destroy, smite, smite down; ppp: hata; infinitive: hantum
slayer of - suffix at the end of the person/creature killed (rather, end member of a reduced compound)
"I will kill;" future first person of √han, kill
Hanuman, a great monkey hero of the Rāmayana.

a kind of goose; Maurer notes that Sanskrit literature talks about a kind of goose which was believed capable of separating pure milk from a misture of milk and water, and that this special ability is often alluded to.
one who takes away, a thief or robber
"Alas! I'm a goner!" literally: struck down, killed. hataḥ is the past passive participle of √han (hanti)
leaving, leaving aside, giving up, abandonment
indeed, surely; also used as an enclitic conjunction, "for," expressing the reason for a preceding action
welfare, benefit, well-being (Maurer says it is the ppp of √dhā, put, place, hence placed or put, but with the sense of "well placed or put"the participle then being used as a noun.)
having abandoned or disregarded; gerund of √hā (juhāti)

Himavat, or the Himālaya mountain; the name means "having snow" or "snowy"; also refers to Himavat, the Himālaya personified as father of Pārvatī, Śiva's wife, also called daughter of the mountain, and also the father of Gaṅga, the Ganges River
devoid of, missing; especially at the end of a compound; The G entry seems to be saying it's a synonym of rahita
cause, impulse, motivation; "the impeller;" genitive = hetoḥ; M says: as a quasi-postposed "for the sake of, for" + genitive
abduct, carry off (G); take, take away, steal (M): infinitive: hartum; aorist: ahārṣīt
"lying in the heart," (beloved?); as a masculine noun, love
bristle, horripilating (hair standing on end from fear)
bristling, horripilated (due to fear); ppp of √hṛṣ (hṛṣyati)
Hṛṣīkeśa, a name for Kṛṣṇa which means "lord of the senses"
delighted G); bristling (of hair, due to excitement) (M)
Hlādinī, a mythical river, name means "the gladdener"
